For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and supportslabor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Patrice

texts.en:
Patrice is 46 years old. She is married with five children, aged between 12 and 25. She would like to use Kiva's loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Xavera

texts.en:
Xavera is 47 years old. She is married with five children. She would like to use Kiva's loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during rice production. She needs to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is married and has one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but has no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

For the past year, she has operated a bodaboda (motorcycle) transport business. Her potential customers are town dwellers. She cites the high cost of maintenance as being her major challenge. With the 25,000 KES, she wants to purchase spare parts and paint her motorcycle. 

She joined Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and paint her motorcycle.

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene, aged 39, is married with six children. He would like to use Kiva's loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizers in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Galib

texts.en:
Galib is a 33-year-old married man. He lives with his wife and mother in a small village of the Bolnisi District. Galib is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, he has a plot of agricultural land where potatoes and maize are grown. He is a very hardworking man and always has high quality products which are sold to local retailers at a good price. In addition, he sometimes works as an artisan and earns income.

Galib decided to start his own business and requested a loan. The start-up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 2,000 USD to purchase a minibus. As the minibus is purchased, he will trade fruits and vegetables, and he will increase the income of his family.

loans.use: to purchase a minibus.

loans.name: Vasil

texts.ru:
Василь – из Берегово. Он работает директором сельской школы. Василь с семьей живет в собственном одноэтажном доме. 
Сумма в 20 000 гривен необходима Василю для того, чтобы улучшить свои жилищные условия. Он давно надеялся сделать пристройку к своему дому, чтобы расширить его на еще одну комнату – гостиную. Василь хотел бы достроить стены, переместить окна, вставить входные двери и, тем самым, сделать дом уютнее.
texts.en: Vasil is from Beregovo.  He is a principal at a local village school, and lives with his family in their very own 1-story house.  He is seeking a loan of 20,000 griven to renovate his home; for the longest time, he's wanted to add a new living room to his house, and, with this loan, he hopes to be able to do just that, as well as to finish building some walls, move some windows elsewhere, and put in a new set of front doors.  By doing so, he hopes to improve his family's living conditions, and make his house more comfortable to live in.

loans.use: renovate his home

loans.name: Mzia

texts.en:
Mzia is 51 years old and lives in the village of Dighomi, near the capital city. She has a grown son, daughter-in-law, toddler grandson and retired mother-in-law in her family. Mzia is a masseuse. She has loyal patients and serves them from her house as well as in their places. She is busy all day long and works hard to generate good income for her family's well being. 

In order to generate additional sources of income, Mzia decided to apply for credit and purchase a car. Her son, Guram, who works as a security guard will start working as a taxi driver. He has a work schedule and will be able to work in his free time. Guram will earn daily money, cover the feeding and everyday expenses of the family. Mzia and her son hope the Kiva loan will be helpful for their family.

loans.use: to buy a car for her son's taxi business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ten bales of secondhand clothes.

loans.name: Ramadhan

texts.en:
Ramadhan is 42 years old. He is married with six children. He has been a maize producer for the past seven years. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support his labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his crop yield. With the profits from his farming he wishes to reinvest in his business so that in the future he can acquire different machines and a tractor that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support his labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 38 years old. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production; he needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With the profits from his farming he wishes to reinvest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and a tractor that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Anayat

texts.en: Anayat is a 28-year-old married woman. She is a mother of six children. She adores her family and her husband works very hard so that his family can have a good and respectable life. Her husband owns a clothing business which is the only source of income for the family. Presently he needs additional capital for the growth of his business. Anayat is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan, for her husband to purchase a variety of clothes to sell. This will allow him to respond quickly to customer needs. He will put aside some of the profits to pay for the electricity and gas bill. Anayat hopes that the loan will be helpful to her husband's business. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase variety of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar is a 32-year-old married father of three children, who has been working in shoe sales for the past five years. In 2010, he opened his current shop, which he has worked hard to develop, to provide his children the best education and living and fulfill his customer’s needs.
Omar is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase his business inventory with newly released winter collection.
Omar's shop is well known in the region, since he is the only one who runs such a business.
He is working hard to develop his business to make sure that he can cover all of his villagers needs.

loans.use: to increase his business inventory with newly released winter collection.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, shortening, beans, soft drinks, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Melvin Antonio

texts.es:
Melvin, sigue cultivando la tierra y en esta ocasión necesita capital para comprar abono, insecticidas, herbicidas y plaguicidas, los cuales le ayudaran a tener muy bien preparada la tierra para la siembra.
Con el préstamo anterior pudo sembrar y recoger una abundante cosecha de maíz, sus ingresos aumentaron, amplio el área de siembra.
Hace un tiempo sufrió un accidente de motocicleta pero eso no fue motivo para dejar de trabajar y luchar por salir adelante, ya esta recuperado.
texts.en:
Melvin continues cultivating the land and occasionally needs capital to buy fertilizer, instecticide, herbicide, and pest control substance so he can treat the land for planting.

With the previous loan he was able to plant and harvest an abundant corn crop and increase his income.  He also expanded the crop area.  Some time ago he suffered a motorcycle accident but that was no reason to stop working and getting ahead.  He is now recovered.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, herbicide and pest control substance.

loans.name: Reina Isabel

texts.es:
Reina Isabel es una mujer joven de 24 años de edad que desde niña se ha dedicado a apoyar a sus padres en las diferentes actividades que desarrolla en el campo como: limpieza, corte, fertilización, recolección, etc. Hoy en día junto a su compañero de hogar siguen ejerciendo las actividades que anteriormente se mencionan ya que en su comunidad es la única fuente de empleo y medio de ingreso para cada una de las familias. Ella es madre de 2 hijos los cuales estudian en el kínder de la comunidad teniendo ella un grado de educación primario cursado hasta el quinto grado por lo que agradece el apoyo financiero y moral de sus padres. Los cultivos de café que ella y su pareja trabajan son propios gracias a una herencia por parte de sus padres los cuales están ubicados a 100 metros de su casa de habitación al cual se trasladan caminando para poder asistirlos.
Ella sueña con ampliar la parcela de tierra que sus padres le heredaron con mucho mas producto, con una mejor variedad, más competitiva y más atractiva por lo que tiene la ilusión de mejorar sus ingresos parta el bienestar de su familia y el futuro de sus hijos. Es por ello que hoy en día ella ha solicitado un financiamiento con el cual comprara 11 unidades de abono 18-46-0, 4 botes de abono foliar y 22 unidades de nutricafe con el cual protegerá y asistirá sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Reina Isabel, 24, is a young woman who since she was a child has helped her parents with the farm chores such as cutting, cleaning, fertilizing and crop harvesting.  Nowadays, together with her common-law partner, she continues with the same activity because in the community where she lives it is the only way to work and earn a living for the families.

She has two children who attend the kindergarten in the community and she, herself, received a fifth grade education thanks to her parents' moral and financial support. The coffee crops she and her partner have belong to the them as she inherited them from her parents.  The land is 100 meters from their house so they walk there to care for them.

Her dream is to add more products to the land she inherited from her parents.  She wants the crop to be of a better variety, more competitive and attractive.  Her goal is to improve her income for her family's well-being and the future of her children.  That is why she is now requesdting a loan to buy 11 units of fertilizer 18-46-0, 4 cans of plant fertlizer and 22 units of Nutricafe to protect and maintain the crops.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her coffee crop.

loans.name: Brigida

texts.es: Brigida, de 26 años es una mujer admirable. Vive en compañía de su esposo e hijo a los que cuida en la casa que heredó de su padre. Su principal ingreso económico se centra en la siembra de papa, maíz y todo tipo de hortalizas, en terrenos agrícolas propios y alquilados. Aprovecha las largas jornadas en el campo para cuidar de sus animales como: vacas, toros, cerdos, “quien  sabe trabajar, dedica todo el día al cuidado de sus sembríos pues es importante tener de buena calidad”, comenta. Al mismo tiempo menciona que aprovecha los toros que posee, para hacer arado con la ayuda de su esposo. Asimismo cuenta que, el fin de semana aprovecha para vender comida, tiene muchos años cocinando y los comensales que visitan su puesto, consumen con frecuencia, de esa manera obtiene un dinero extra. Este es el primer crédito con KIVA, se siente feliz, pues tiene el capital necesario para mejorar su negocio y por ende su calidad de vida. Además le gusta pertenecer a su asociación, porque sus integrantes son personas solidarias y trabajadoras. Brigida, invertirá los S/.800 soles en la compra de abono orgánico para sus sembríos.
texts.en:
Brígida, 26, is an admirable woman who lives with her husband and children in the house she inherited from her parents.  Her main source of income is growing potatoes, corn and all types of vegetables on her own land as well as on rented land.  She takes advantage of the long workdays to care for her animals: cows, oxen, and pigs.  She says "People who know how to work dedicate their entire day to caring for the crops in order to get good quality."  She also takes advantage of the oxen to plough with her husband.

On weekends she sells food, as she has been cooking for many years and has frequent customers; so this is a way to earn extra income.  This is her first KIVA loan and she is very happy because she will have the necessary capital to improve her business and quality of life.  And, she enjoys being a member of the association because the other members are supportive, hard-working people.  She will use the 800 PEN loan to buy organic fertilizer for her crops.

loans.use: To buy organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Maria Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
Teresa, con el fin de aprovechar la próxima temporada de fin de año se está preparando para surtir su negocio con variedad de artículos, solicita capital para comprar ropa, juguetes, sombrillas y otros, teniendo lo necesario para ofrecer a su público sus beneficios serán los mismos que obtuvo con el crédito anterior como lo son mejores ganancias, un inventario muy completo, más clientes satisfechos y un negocio más competitivo.
Su familia se encuentra muy saludable y disfrutando de los cambios que han tenido en su economía, pues ya no tienen preocupaciones por deudas, ni por no contar con artículos que sus clientes necesitaban.
texts.en:
Teresa wants to take advantage of the upcoming end of year holiday season to stock her business with a variety of articles.  She is requesting a loan to buy clothing, toys, sun umbrellas, etc. so she can have everything she needs to offer to her customers.  The advantages will be the same as those she obtained with the previous loan which are more profits, a very complete inventory, satisfied customers and a competitive business.

Her family is very healthy and enjoying the changes they have had in their economy, since they do not have to worry about debts.  And Teresa does not have to worry about not having the merchandise her customers need.

loans.use: To buy clothing, toys, sun umbrellas, etc.

loans.name: Vasil

texts.ru:
Василь – из Виноградово. Уже не первый год занимается тепличным хозяйством, держит 3 теплицы – одна размером в 2 сотки, другие – по 2 сотки. В теплицах Василь выращивает цветы и огурцы. Наемных рабочих не берет, в бизнесе задействована вся семья. Земельный участок находится прямо возле дома. 
Сумма в 15 000 гривен понадобилась Василю для того, чтобы обновить состояние теплиц и купить все нужное для сельскохозяйственного сезона, а именно купить пленку на теплицу, а также семена цветов и огурцов, горшки и дрова для отопления внутри теплиц. Со временем Василь планирует сконструировать еще одну теплицу, так как земля для этого есть.
texts.en: Vasil is from Vinogradovo.  He is an experienced greenhouse grower who has three greenhouses - one has two arches, and others are one arch apiece.  Vasil grows flowers and cucumbers in his greenhouses.  He does not have any staff, since his whole family is involved in the business.  His plot is located right next to his house.  Vasil needs 15,000 hryvnas to make repairs to his greenhouses and to buy everything he needs for the growing season, specifically plastic film for the greenhouses and seeds for flowers, cucumbers, peas and firewood to heat the greenhouses.  In time, Vasil plans to build another greenhouse, as he has the land for it.

loans.use: to purchase plastic film, seeds, pots and wood for greenhouses

loans.name: Kadior Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe fait partie d'un banc villageois inauguré le 23 Mars 2013. Ce groupe est constitué de femmes qui ont une même vision et une bonne progression en épargne et en crédit. Madame Sounkarou qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est la représentante du groupe. Elle est mariée, âgée de 50 ans et mère d'une fille de 17 ans. Elle s'active dans la vente d'habit depuis plusieurs années. Elle est couturière au village artisanal. Elle va acheter avec le prêt demandé 25 pièces de tissu. Les serviront de prendre en charge les frais de scolarité de sa fille.
texts.en: This group is part of the village bank inaugurated 23 march 2013. This group is comprised of women with similar vision and a good progression of credit and savings. Mrs Sounkarou, seen in the far right in the photo raising her hand, is the representative of the group. She is a 50 year old married woman and mother of a 17 year old girl. She has been selling clothing for several years. She is a seamstress in an artisanal village. She plans to use this loan to purchase 25 pieces of fabric. Profits will be used to take care of the education costs of her daughter.

loans.use: purchase clothes

loans.name: Sylvain

texts.en:
Sylvain is 25 years old. He is married with one child. He would like to use his Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Felicien

texts.en:
Felicien is 42 years old. He is married with seven children. With the Kiva loan, he will pay labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Françoise Paul's Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Françoise Paul (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 46 ans. Françoise Paul est mariée à un vitrier du nom de Hervé. Le couple a un enfant à sa charge, qui n'est pas scolarisé. Françoise Paul vit avec son mari et son enfant à charge. Les charges du ménage sont supportées par Françoise Paul et son mari. Françoise Paul est une coiffeuse. Parallèlement, Françoise Paul vend des tissus et des chaussures dans sa boutique à son domicile. Françoise Paul s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin et aussi au Togo. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Françoise Paul s’associe aux autres membres de son groupe pour solliciter un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: This group is comprised of three women living in the same neighborhood. The representative of the group, named Françoise Paul (seen in the photo with her hand raised), is 46 years old. Françoise is married to a window fitter named Hervé. The couple has one child, who does not attend school. Françoise Paul lives with her husband her child. All needs of the family are shared by both parents. Françoise Paul is a hairdresser. On the side, she also sells fabric and shoes from her home. She stocks up on merchandise at markets in Benin and Togo. In order to reinforce her activity, Françoise Paul is collaborating with other members of her group in order to ask for their first loan from ALIDE.

loans.use: purchase hair extensions, fabric and shoes

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 50 years old. He is married with five children. He would like to use his Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Saiqa

texts.en:
Saiqa, age 26, is a mother of four children. Her husband owns an embroidery shop in the market. This is the only source of income for the family. He needs to purchase a new variety of embroidery material to resell. However due to lack of money he finds it difficult. This loan will help him to offer more variety to his customers and to continue his work efficiently and professionally. 

For that reason, his wife, Saiqa is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, BRAC Pakistan, with the goal of helping her husband. He will purchase an embroidery machine and new variety of embroidery materials. Saiqa is feeling happy that she will be able to help her husband with the loan amount. She is thankful to Kiva lenders and to BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine and new variety of embroidery materials.

loans.name: Natela

texts.en:
Natela, age 47, is from the village of Dighomi, where she lives with her 18-year-old son. Natela’s son is a cook in a restaurant and Natela works as a dishwasher. Both of the family members get a monthly salary and they don’t have their own business. Natela works throughout each day to generate income, but her earnings are too small to save and improve the family's standard of living. The family lives below the poverty line and receives a small amount of social assistance from the local government. 

Natela would like to start up a clothing sales business in her community in order to earn an additional income. She has applied for this loan in order to purchase a supply of clothing at wholesale prices to start her new business. Since there are not many clothing stores in her village, Natela is confident that her endeavor will meet a high demand. She intends to develop positive relationships with her customers and expects to attain a good profit from her new business. This start-up loan offers Natela a good chance to earn a more stable income and improve her family's living conditions in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of clothing and start a trading business in her community.

loans.name: Eugénie's Group

texts.fr: C'est un groupe de quatre personnes qui sont des amies. La représentante du groupe du nom de Eugénie (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 58 ans. Eugénie est mariée à un certain Henri. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont un à leur charge. Eugénie n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Eugénie vend depuis trente ans, divers produits vivriers (maïs, riz, haricot, huile végétale) dans une région du Bénin. Eugénie s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et en vue élargir son activité, Eugénie sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé, ensemble  avec les autres membres de son groupe. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: This group is comprised of four friends. The representative of the group, Eugénie (seen in the photo with her hand raised) is 58 years old. Eugénie is married to a man named Henri. The couple have four children, one of whom they are still responsible for. Eugénie did not attend school. In order to cover the family's needs, Eugénie has been selling diverse food supplies (corn, rice, beans, vegetable oil) for the past thirty years. She stocks up on merchandise in the market in Benin. In order to satisfy her customers and increase her activity, Eugénie is asking for her first loan from ALIDE, together with the other members of her group. This loan will allow them to better respond to customer requests and increase their profits.

loans.use: purchase food supplies (corn, rice, beans, vegetable oil)

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 43 years old. He is a father of four children. He would like to use his Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay for labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Maclaren Group

texts.en:
Devis, who is in his mid 50s is married with four sons two of them are still at school. He has been running a general store since 1995. He works from 06.00am to 08.00pm each working day and and is able to make a fair return each month. 

This is Devis's eleventh loan request from Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzani. He will use it to buy more stock for the general store, fix the fridge and the door of the premises where he puts his business fridge. With the previous loans all of which he paid back successfully, he restocked his general store with missing items so as to maintain his sales level. Devis used his business profit to pay college fees for his children, reinvested in the business and saved for his retirement benefits. He started building a house for renting. Devis dreams that one day will be able to finish building his house for renting and to have a better life. 

Devis will share this loan with his loan group "Maclaren" which totals eight members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock for the general store, fix the fridge and the door of the premises where he keeps his fridge.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is a 51-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband and son in a small village of Sachkhere district. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have a plot of agricultural land, where they have walnut trees, maize and haricot beans. They work hard to have a good harvest, which is sold to local retailers. Her husband and son also work as artisans and get small additional income. 

Svetlana decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start-up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 3,100 GEL to purchase two cows. When the cows are purchased, Svetlana will start producing cheese to sell. The Start-up loan will be a great support for the family.

loans.use: to purchase cows.

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
Leonard is 48 years old. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Venuste

texts.en:
Venuste is 47 years old. He has been a rice farmer for the past twenty years. With the Kiva loan, he would like to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers to use during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Maria Haidee

texts.es:
María, tiene 29 años, es una madre que disfruta de sus tres hijos junto a su esposo. Debido a la necesidad de generar ingresos para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar, se decidió por salir a vender tamales de elote en el centro de la cuidad y en sus alrededores, para ella no se le hace difícil esta actividad la respalda mucho tiempo de experiencia y la administrado muy bien.
Comprar elotes, aceite, leña y ollas; para poder elaborar una mayor cantidad de productos, con esto tendrá mejores ingresos, aumento en sus ventas y materia prima para trabajar y cumplir con sus compromisos.
María aspira a tener un negocio más amplio para que su economía sea estable y forjar un futuro con muchas oportunidades en la educación de sus hijos y cubrir las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria is 29 years old and a happy mother to the three children she has with her husband. Owing to the need to make money to help her husband with household expenses, she decided to go sell sweet corn tamales in the city center and surrounding areas. This was not a difficult thing for her, since she has long experience behind her and knows very well what she is doing. 

 Buying corn on the cob, oil, firewood, and pots, so she can prepare more products, will allow her to make more money. She can also increase her sales and raw materials for working with, and this way she can fulfill her commitments. Maria aspires to expand her business in order to have stable finances and forge a future full of educational opportunities for her children and provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy corn on the cob, oil, firewood, and pots

loans.name: John

texts.en: John, a hardworking father of two living in Fort Portal, Uganda, is  a farmer and also works as a catechist in a local church. Like most farmers, he is challenged by unpredictable weather changes and price fluctuations, while his desire is to diversify his farming activities to include both annual and perennial crops. John is requesting a loan to plant maize to sell.

loans.use: To plant maize

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is a 41-year-old married man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is in involved the transport business, alongside farming, in order to boost his income. 

He faces challenges of prolonged rainy seasons that make roads impassible and high cost of fuel, while his dreams are to own at least four motorcycles which he intends to hire out and the riders will be expected to remit 80% of the daily earnings. Thomas intends to use the loan to buy a new motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Cyriaque

texts.en:
Cyriaque, a 40-year-old married father of three, is requesting a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers to increase rice production and support farm labor costs. He wishes to reinvest profits into his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en:
Yashar is 29 years old. He is single and lives with his parents and sister. His family have been IDP (internally displacted persons) from Füzuli city for twenty years and now live in Bala Bahmanli village of Füzuli. Yashar’s mother Husniya is a housewife who helps Yashar in his business. His father Ali is a taxi driver and sister Gunay is a tailor.

Yashar has been in the animal breeding business for three years. He buys little cows, raises them, and sells them in the local bazaar to earn money to live on. Yashar wants to develop his business, so he needs 1800 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat) to buy more cows.

Yashar is thankful for this aid from Komak and Kiva organizations. He wants to buy more cows and in the future to produce dairy products and sell them.

loans.use: to buy more cows

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida is a 39-year-old married lady. She has expertise in hand embroidery and has been using her skills to provide financial support to her family for many years. She started this line of work at a very young age. During the initial years of her business, she barely made enough of money to purchase the required material. 

Today, she is proud to be famous in her community as the best at making beautiful patterns with thread and beads. Her designs are much in demand and she has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her home. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of RKR 30000, to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins, and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand. This is her second year with Kashf Foundation; she has shown good repayment behavior.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls.

loans.name: Misbha

texts.en:
Misbha is vigorous lady and a mother of four children. 

She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she requested a loan of PKR 20,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to create a means of increasing revenues so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her fourth loan cycle and is thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: To buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Sheher

texts.en:
Sheher is a 32-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband, who is also shown in the photo. Her husband assists her by purchasing stock of goods from the market and dealing with customers by sitting at the shop. Over time they have become popular in their community for providing good quality products, and they make enough to meet the expenses of their three children. 

Currently, she is requesting a loan of PKR 35,000 to buy packs of salts, biscuits and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits and beverages.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 30-year-old single man who works in the agriculture business to make his living. Mohamad has an agricultural tractor that he uses to help farmers in doing necessary agricultural work.  He also works in transporting students to and from school as an additional income business. Mohamad is a hard worker who seeks perfection in both businesses to make sure that they will provide him with a good living. 

He is acquiring a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, to make necessary maintenance to his tractor, which is his main source of living.

Mohamad is working hard to hard to keep on developing his businesses to make sure that, in the future, he'll have a wide agricultural services company in addition to a transportation company.

loans.use: To make necessary maintenance to his tractor.

loans.name: Zaheen

texts.en:
Zaheen is a 27-year-old married woman and the mother of three children. 

She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she requested a loan of PKR 25,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to create a means of increasing revenues so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. 

She is in her third loan cycle with good repayment history. She hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children in future.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Farhat

texts.en:
Farhat is a 36-year-old married lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she requested a loan of PKR 30,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to meet the demands of her customers on time. 

She is in her second loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. She wishes to provide a better standard of living to her four children.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Hafiizan

texts.en: Hafiizan had a difficult time after her husband's business failure. She decided to work with her husband to support her family for a better future. Two years ago she began sewing work in her house. She sews for the people living around her house and uses the income to support her entire family. She is the mother six children and is motivated to provide them with good quality food, health and clothing.  She has now attained a regular list of customers but due to a lack of funds she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. She has applied for a loan of 30,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR) to purchase more spools of thread, along with the packs of lace and ribbons. These will help her to sew more dresses in less time. She is currently in her second loan cycle and has a good credit history.

loans.use: to purchase more spools of thread along with packs of lace and ribbons.

loans.name: Cesar Vallejo De V.e.s Group

texts.es: Inés  de 43  Años de edad soltera y sin hijos, Inés  se dedica hace  3 años al servicio de costura remalle, Inés  confecciona prendas de vestir, en un pequeño local (alquilado) con el fin de progresar día a día y salir adelante, Inés   a sabido ganarse a los clientes  y así poder mejorar su calidad de vida. Inés solicito el préstamo para comprar telas y poder  confeccionar ropa  de vestir a la vez  Inés   y todos los integrantes se encuentran  agradecidos  con Kiva  por el préstamo otorgado  y por la confianza que se  les ha sido brindada. Inés  esta parada y se le distingue por su pantalón marrón,  Se despide  Dejando la promesa  que cumplirá todas sus metas propuestas.
texts.en:
Inés, 43, is single and doesn't have children. For three years, she has worked by repairing clothing. Inés makes clothing in a small rented space with the goal of moving forward. Inés knew how to gain customers so she can improve her quality of life.

Inés is requesting this loan to buy fabric for dressmaking. Inés and all the other members are grateful to Kiva for the loan and for for believing in them. In the photo, Inés is standing and wearing brown pants. She promises to fulfill all her goals.

loans.use: to buy fabric for dressmaking

loans.name: Ignace

texts.en:
Ignace is age 32. He is a father of four, three of whom go to school. With the loan, he would like to use his Kiva loan to pay labor costs to buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and to pay labor costs for rice production.

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
Bushra is a 30-year-old married woman who has run a business selling milk with her husband for the past seven years. She has four buffalo and one cow, which she uses for milk for the people of her locality. Bushra has become famous for providing good-quality milk and she makes enough to contribute to her family's income. 

She has gradually improved her business with the support of the Kashf Foundation. Currently she is in her sixth loan cycle and has applied for a loan of PKR 50,000. This will allow her to purchase one more cow. Bushra is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her and will bring positive changes to her business.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow.

loans.name: Samina

texts.en:
Ms. Samina is married and the mother of five. 

She has been running a business of trading cloth for many years. She purchases a variety of cloth from the main city and then sells it to the people of her vicinity. She has become famous for selling good-quality cloth in her community.

Samina has requested a loan of PKR 45,000 from Kashf Foundation to buy stocks of different cloth for the winter season, by taking into account the choices and tastes of her customers. In this way, she will be able to earn more income through her greater sales. 

She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan and wants to grow her business. She dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard efforts in her business.

loans.use: To buy stocks of different cloth for the winter season.

loans.name: Nawab

texts.en:
Nawab, age 35, has been doing business making shoes for many years. She is an energetic person and eager to support her family. She is running her business with the support of her husband and makes enough to provide the basic necessities for her five children, including food, health and education. 

It’s her sixth year with Kashf Foundation. Currently she applied for a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy additional material to make shoes, including leather, artificial leather, plastic soles, etc. In this way she can handle the growing demand for her shoes in the market. She wishes to spend part of the revenue she makes on providing a better standard of living for her family members.

loans.use: to buy additional material to make shoes including leather, artificial leather, plastic soles, etc.

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en:
Shabana is a 37-year-old married woman and a mother of five. 

She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing services of tailoring in her community. She has been doing it for many years. She very well knows the techniques of stitching. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she requested a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy a stock of threads in different colors along with packs of zippers and buttons to meet the increasing demand. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy a stock of threads in different colors along with packs of zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Dyanah Wared 50430 Group

texts.en:
Hind is the featured borrower of Dyanah Wared 50430 Group. She joined the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua because they have always been neighbors and friends.

Hind is a 41-year-old married mother of two children. She works as an accountant to support her husband who works in pasting floor tiles. Hind's loan will be invested in paying for her children school tuition fees. Hind is the first lady standing at the left side.

As for the other group members, Nisrine is the second from the left, Diana is the lady in red, and Noura is the first from the right.

loans.use: to pay her children's school tuition fees

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 47 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have six children. He would like to use the Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Asima

texts.en: Asima is 30 years old and a vigorous lady; she has been stitching clothes for the past five years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds she is unable to meet the daily demand of her customers. For this reason she requested a loan of Rs 15,000 to Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of thread in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to create a means of increasing revenue so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her 2nd loan cycle and thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: to buy more spools of thread in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons

loans.name: Victorina Del Carmen

texts.es:
Victorina, es una mujer que lucha por salir adelante con sus hijos de 2, 4 y 6 años, es una madre soltera que vive con sus padres y se ha visto en la necesidad de emprender un  negocio propio para cubrir los gastos de sus hijos, hace mucho tiempo se empezó a vender accesorio de uso personal lo inicio por cuenta propia y no se le dificulta realizar está actividad porque es algo que disfruta hacerlo.
Invertirá en la compra de ganchos, diademas, moños, peines, aretes de bisutería, etc., con lo que surtirá sus productos y podrá cumplir con las demandas de sus clientes.
Sueña con ampliar su negocio, salir de la deuda, dar a sus hijos mejor alimentación, educación, y salud.
texts.en:
Victorina is a woman working hard to move forward with her children ages 2, 4, and 6. She is a single mother who lives with her parents and saw the need to start her own business to cover her children's expenses. A long time ago, she started selling personal accessories. She started on her own and it was easy for her to decide on this sector because she enjoys doing it.

She will invest in buying hooks, hairbands, ribbons, combs, earrings, and more. This will help her stock up on products to meet her customers' demands. She dreams of growing her business, getting out of debt, and giving her children better food, education, and health.

loans.use: to buy hooks, hairbands, ribbons, combs, earrings, and more.

loans.name: Nargis

texts.en:
Nargis is a 31-year-old married woman. 

She has a business manufacturing "waan," which is a thread-like material used in making wooden bed frames on four legs. She offers various types of "waan" in different colors and has become famous for providing good quality material in her community. 

Nargis operates the machine at home with the help of her husband and is able to manage her household efficiently.  

This is her third year with Kashf Foundation. Currently, she is applying for a loan of PKR 30,000 to buy another machine to make "waan" with fresh quality thread, to increase her sales. She is hopeful to get boost in her earnings and wishes to expand her business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy another machine to make "waan."

loans.name: Tahsina

texts.en:
Ms. Tehsina is a married woman who is living with her husband in Punjab, Pakistan. For about 5 years she has been in the work of hand embroidery. She makes beautiful patterns for the people of her community. Her designs are much in demand and she has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her home.

To help her to continue her operations, she has requested a loan of Rs. 20,000 to buy reels of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment. In this way she would be able to cater to more customers consistently. She is hopeful of getting an increase in her income by targeting more customers. 

Tehsina dreams of her children's bright future and desires to build her own house, as she is now living in a rented house with her family. She is very thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: To buy reels of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones.

loans.name: Ishrat

texts.en: Ishrat, age 25, has dealt in the business of selling animals for many years. She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, brings them up and sells them out near the occasion of Eid-ul-Azha (a religious event in Muslims countries). She has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf foundation. Currently, she requested a loan of Rs.30,000 to purchase two more goats. She is in her 3rd loan cycle with good repayment history.  She hopes to generate more profits so she can better support her family.

loans.use: to purchase two more goats.

loans.name: Asmati

texts.en:
Asmati, age 42, is a widow from the village of Vardisubani ("street of roses" in English) where she lives with her two children. She is actively involved in an agricultural business and cultivates a piece of land where eggplants are grown. Asmati sells her produce locally. Besides that, she rents agricultural land to earn income and feed her children. 

 In order to meet her increasing family expenses, Asmati decided to start her own business. Asmati has noticed a high demand for used clothing in the market as local people can’t afford to buy new clothing due to their poverty. In response to the local market demand, she has requested a loan to purchase stock of used clothing to sell among her community members with a price mark-up. She plans to invest the profit in the same business and develop it in the future. Asmati hopes this loan will change her life.

loans.use: to purchase used clothing for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 31 years. He has spent six years in the farming field. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for use during maize production

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas lives in the Kongowea area north of Mombasa Kenya. He is 36 years old and married with four children. He runs a retail shop in the market and the business has been in operation for two years now. 

Thomas wants to buy cereals and soap for his business. He knew Milango through friends who invited him to join so that he can be able to access funding for his business. He hopes that the business will grow in to a wholesale business in the next five years despite the challenges of competition and price instability. The income that he will raise from the business will improve his standards of living and also educate his children.

loans.use: to buy cereals and soap

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is a 28-year-old married man. He lives in the Telavi district with his wife and mother. His mother is provided with a retirement pension. His wife works as a sales lady at a local pharmacy and gets 350 Gel per month. 

Zurab is unemployed now, in spite of having a high education diploma. He decided to start his own business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of $4,500 for purchasing a car. Once the car is purchased, he will serve local people as a taxi driver and will generate income.

loans.use: to purchase a car and work as a taxi driver.

loans.name: Haseena

texts.en:
Haseena is a 38-year-old, married woman and a mother of seven. She has been running a business selling cloth for many years. She purchases a variety of fabrics from the main city and then sells to the people of her vicinity. She has become famous for selling good quality cloth in her community. 

Haseena requested a loan of PKR 20,000 from Kashf Foundation to buy a stock of different sorts of cloth for the winter season, taking into account the choices and tastes of her customers. In this way, she would be able to earn more income through her greater sales. She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan and wants to grow her business. She dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to buy a stock of different fabrics for the winter season.

loans.name: Miracle's Group

texts.en:
Miracles Group is currently in its forth loan cycle. They sell products like dippers, ladies' shoes, cooking oil, gari (cassava flour), beans and electrical gadgets.

Gladys is 44 years old, married and has two children. She is the group representative and she sells electrical gadgets from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. every day. Her effort has earned her good customers who order regularly and are very satisfied with her service.
 
Gladys' dream is to have a well equipped shop so that she can keep working and gain more customers and earn more profit.

Gladys has asked for this loan so that she can purchase CD players and radios to sell to her customers. This will help her keep working as she strives to grow and improve life for herself and her family.

Gladys, together with eight others, will need GHS 6,800 to buy stock and improve their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase CD players and radios to sell.

loans.name: Zubida

texts.en:
Zubida is a 55-year-old widow and a mother of three. She has been involved in business selling cloth in her community for a period of about 6 years. Zubida buys different fabrics in various colors and designs from the market at wholesale rates and then sells them to the people of her community. She has a varied customer base and is able to earn enough through her business. 

Zubida is requesting a loan of 50,000 PKR from the Kashf Foundation to buy a wide variety of fabrics in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory. Zubida expects a boost in her earnings with her loan and she plans to spend the part of her profits on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of fabrics in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani is 59 years old and married. She has been doing a business of bangles sales for many years. She buys bangles from the wholesale markets at lower rates and then sells them to the people of her community at a profit. Her husband’s income is not enough to fulfill the family needs. Therefore she started her own business to contribute to the family income. 

Rani has requested a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy the latest variety of bangles in different colors and designs. This will help her to increase her sales. She is in her 3rd loan cycle with good repayment history. She wants to expand her business to provide a better standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to buy the latest variety of bangles in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Heydar

texts.en:
Heydar is a 53-year-old married man and father of three children. He has been in agricultural for more than 29 years. He is very hard-working and passionate about his work. His main engagement is corn sowing. He sells his crops in the central bazaar to make profits in order to support his family.

In order to improve the living conditions of his family, he plans to expand his business. This requires a lot of dedication and effort. 

Heydar has applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN. This loan is for the purpose of buying new fertilizer and seeds. It will help him grow more vegetables and fruits in order to obtain more revenues in the coming autumn, which will help him to cover his family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Huma

texts.en: Huma is a married woman who has run a beauty parlour for five years. She offers many services to her customers such as make-up, hair styling and facials and has become very famous in her street. In order to meet with the increasing demands of her customers, she is interested in buying a greater variety of cosmetics products for her parlour. But because of her lack of cash in hand, she contacted Kashf Foundation to apply for a loan. She needs a loan of 40,000 Pakistani rupees to buy hair care products, skin products and bleaching and whitening creams in large quantities. With these, she is hopeful of consistently catering for more customers. With the help of the loan, she will not only purchase a variety of products but also be able to meet her household expenses.

loans.use: to buy hair care products, skin products and bleaching and whitening creams in large quantities.

loans.name: Paulina's Group

texts.en:
Paulina is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Paulina was born in Teshie township, in a coastal part of Ghana, 38 years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has three children; all are attending primary and junior high school. 

For six years now, Paulina has been operating a cold store by selling both fish and meat. 

She and her group members have applied for a loan of GHS 2,400 to expand their businesses. 

Paulina will use her share of the loan (GHS 800) to buy more fish from the harbor to stock her cold store.

loans.use: To buy more fish from the harbor to stock her cold store.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is a 27-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband (the man shown in the photo) at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing stocks of goods from the market, as he has maintained many contacts over the years. 

She is a mother of two children, and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing, and health. 

She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store. 

She is expecting a boost in her earnings, and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages.

loans.name: Saima

texts.en:
Saima is a 32-year-old married woman and a mother of two. She has been running a business selling clothes for many years. She purchases a variety of clothes from the main city and then sells to the people in her vicinity. She has become famous for selling good quality clothes in her community. 

She requested a loan of PKR 35,000 from Kashf Foundation to buy a stock of clothes in different colors and sizes for the winter season by taking into account the choices and tastes of her customers. In this way, she would be able to earn more income through greater sales. 

Saima is in her 5th loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. She dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard efforts in her business.

loans.use: to buy a stock of clothes in different colors and sizes for the winter season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of fabric.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flowers, paper, tape, and other items for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more provisions for resale.

loans.name: Dirar

texts.en:
Dirar is a 53-year-old married father of one child who has been working as a school bus driver since 2005. He has also worked in furniture making for forty years, but the low income from that business forced him to work in the transportation sector for additional income.

Dirar is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, to pay for his child's school registration fees, tuition fees, books and stationery. His good reputation provides him  customers support and loyalty.

He hopes that one day he'll buy a bigger bus where he can serve more customers and at the same time increase his income.

loans.use: To pay for his child's school registration fees, tuition fees, books and stationery

loans.name: Marcel

texts.en:
Marcel is age 48. He is a father of three. With the Kiva loan, he would like to pay labor costs and buy fertilizers during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Gaspard

texts.en:
Gaspard is 45 years old; he is married with four children. He has been a maize farmer for the past six years. 

He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs, and to buy fertilizer during rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer to increase his production. 

With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer, and to support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a hardworking man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda; he used the previous loan to pay school fees for his children.

John's main business is selling second-hand clothing, in addition to farming as an additional income source. He faces challenges of limited capital, however, he has a vision of educating his children to higher levels of learning and owning a modern boutique. 

John intends to use the loan to pay school fees for his daughter.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his daughter.

loans.name: Maya

texts.en:
This is Maya, who is 44 years old and lives in Tbilisi city. She is married with one child. Maya and her husband are running a car rental business and earn a monthly income. As their earnings are not enough to cover utilities and food costs, Maya has decided to diversify the business and start up a small café, where doner will be sold. Doner (kebab/sandwich/gyro) has become a very popular fast-food dish in the last several years in Georgia. 

According to Maya’s estimation, sales will be high as the location where she plans to start her cafe is crowded with people. She has already hired the commercial space and needs money to purchase all the needed equipment and raw materials. The income from the café will be a great support for the family as it will generate additional income. Maya appreciates your kindness.

loans.use: to start up a food cafe.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy three bags of kale, one carton of tomatoes and three kilograms of onions.

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz is a married lady who sells animals in her community. She buys animals, such as baby goats, at low prices and brings them up and sells them in the market at higher prices. Shahnaz makes enough through her business to contribute in the family income. She is very experienced and has good market contacts. 

Shahnaz is requesting a 20,000 PKR loan from Kashf Foundation to purchase two more goats to improve her business and provide for her household expenses. She will use her loan to definitely expand her business and improve her income.

loans.use: to purchase two goats

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of food ingredients, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demands.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of food ingredients, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current stock levels.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 27 years old. He is a hardworking married man who lives in Hoima, Uganda. Godfrey runs a produce business and has been able to provide the basics for his family with the proceeds from his business. He is a good father who desires to educate his children through university. Godfrey also wants to start a number of sustainable, income-generating activities. His major business challenges include the high cost of transport and price fluctuation.

Godfrey is requesting a loan to buy maize and groundnuts to sell. In the future, he wants to become a model farmer in his village.

loans.use: to buy maize and groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: Ms Abida is a 38-year-old married woman whose husband is a labourer. She has five children and a total of seven members in her household but her husband was previously the only income earner of the family. It was very tough for Abida to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband. Thus she decided to help her husband by starting a business selling spreads, bed sheets and pillow covers. She brings different verities from a wholesale market and sells them in her area. She wants a loan of 20,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR) to purchase a greater variety of bed covers and spreads to cater for the tastes and choices of her customers. She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan and wants to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase more bed covers and spreads.

loans.name: Hernan

texts.es: Hernán  de 25 años de edad,  soltero y sin hijos, es una agradable estudiante de la facultad Administración de negocios internacionales  que estudia mucho para alcanzar sus metas en la vida. Hernán está culminando sus estudios con éxitos y poder ser un buen administrador. Con el préstamo otorgado lo invertirá  en seguir pagando su matrícula, para el pago de sus pensiones universitarias  y  realizar la compra  de útiles de estudio que necesita. Hernán   se encuentra muy agradecido  por la ayuda brindada y se despide con muchos deseos de culminar sus metas propuestas agradece a Edaprospo y kiva.
texts.en:
Hernán is 25, single and has no children. He is a likable student in the International Business Administration department who studies a great deal to achieve his goals in life. He is successfully completing his studies to be a good administrator.

Hernán will use the loan to continue paying his tuition, for university housing and to buy the school supplies he needs. He is very grateful to Edaprospo and Kiva for the help provided and takes his leave eager to achieve his goals

loans.use: to pay his tuition.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more vegetables, indirectly helping her boost her overall sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of bread for resale

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 32 years old and is married with two children. She is a farmer. The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.  

Beatrice is requesting a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer to produce maize. She needs fertilizer to increase her production. With profits from her farm, Beatrice wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors to improve her capacity and yield.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to produce maize
